ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Opens a catalog in browse mode.

[Syntax: CATALOG=<libref.>SAS-catalog] 
      
Specifies the catalog containing device information.
Specifies that you are using program mode.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: ADD device-entry required-parameters <optional-parameters>; 
      
Adds a new device entry to the catalog selected by the CATALOG= option in the 
PROC GDEVICE statement. The device entry is initialized with NULL values for 
most parameters.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: MODULE=driver-module] 
          
Specifies the name of the corresponding executable driver module for the device.

[Syntax: XMAX=width <IN | CM | PT>] 
          
Specifies the width of the addressable graphics display area; affects the horizontal 
resolution of the device and the horizontal dimension of the graphics output area.

[Syntax: YMAX=height <IN | CM | PT>] 
          
Specifies the height of the addressable graphics display area; affects the vertical 
resolution of the device and the vertical dimension of the graphics output area.

[Syntax: XPIXELS=width-in-pixels] 
          
Specifies the width of the addressable display area in pixels and in conjunction 
with XMAX determines the horizontal resolution for the device.

[Syntax: YPIXELS=height-in-pixels] 
          
Specifies the height of the addressable display area in pixels and in conjunction 
with YMAX determines the horizontal resolution for the device.

[Syntax: LCOLS=landscape-columns] 
          
Sets the number of columns in the graphics output area for landscape orientation.

[Syntax: LROWS=landscape-rows] 
          
Sets the number of rows in the graphics output area for landscape orientation.

[Syntax: PCOLS=portrait-columns] 
          
Sets the number of columns in the graphics output area for portrait orientation.

[Syntax: PROWS=portrait-rows] 
          
Sets the number of rows in the graphics output area for portrait orientation.

Syntax: ASPECT=scaling-factor

where scaling-factor is a nonnegative integer or real number that determines the 
ratio of width to height for graphics elements. If you specify ASPECT=1, each 
graphics element has equal horizontal and vertical scaling factors; ASPECT=2 scales 
the graphics element twice as wide as its height; and so on. If ASPECT= is not 
specified or is set to 0 or null, SAS/GRAPH uses the aspect ratio of the hardware 
device.
Specifies whether to generate hard copy automatically.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Prints a copy of the graph automatically.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Suppresses printing a copy of the graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies whether devices with continuous paper or automatic paper feed should roll 
or feed the paper automatically for the next graph. 
 
For PostScript devices, if AUTOFEED is unaltered, the PostScript file is unchanged. If you specify 
NOAUTOFEED and do not select a PPD file with the PPDFILE option, a PostScript Level 1 MANUALFEED 
command is added to the driver output. If you specify NOAUTOFEED and select a PPD that contains a 
MANUALFEED option, the procedure code for that MANUALFEED option is sent. If there is no MANUALFEED 
option in the PPD, no MANUALFEED code is sent.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the device to feed new paper automatically for the next graph.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Suppresses the automatic paper feed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the background color of the graphics output.
Controls whether to use cell alignment.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the device to use cell alignment. In that case SAS/GRAPH attempts to place hardware (or simulated  hardware) characters inside character cells. This restriction on the location of characters means that  in some cases the SAS/GRAPH procedure can generate axes that do not occupy the entire procedure output  area or might be unable to create the requested graph.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Suppresses cell alignment, causing the procedure to use the entire procedure output area and place  axis and tick mark labels without regard to cell alignment.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies whether the device--resident font is used when no font or FONT=NONE is specified in a SAS 
statement. 

The device--resident font is not used if you changed the HPOS= and VPOS= graphics options from 
the default, or if you used the HEIGHT= option in a SAS statement and the device does not have 
scalable characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the device-resident font when you do not specify a font in a SAS program.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the characters using the SIMULATE font and suppresses the use of all  device--resident fonts, regardless of values you specify in other SAS statements.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies a device-resident font by associating a CHARTYPE number with a device-resident font. 
Also defines a default size to use with that font.

Syntax: CHARTYPE=hardware-font-chartype  

hardware-font-chartype 
is a nonnegative integer from 0 to 999. hardware-font-chartype refers to the actual number for 
the device-resident font you want to use as listed in the Chartype window of the device entry 
for the selected device driver. By default, CHARTYPE is 0, which is the default device-resident 
font for the device.
          
Selects the number of the default hardware character set.
Specifies whether SAS/GRAPH should use the device's hardware circle-drawing capability, if available.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware circle- and arc-drawing capability of the device.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software move and draw commands to draw circles and arcs.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CMAP=('from-color : to-color' <...,'from-color-n : to-color-n'>)
    
Specifies a color map for the device.

[Syntax: COLORS=<(colors-list | NONE)>] 
          
Specifies the foreground colors used to produce your graphics output if you do not specify colors 
explicitly in program statements.
Specifies a color StatementOptionType.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: SAS predefined color names.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Red-green-blue (RGB) color specifications.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to use the device's hardware dashed-line capability, if available.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware dashed-line drawing capability of the device when  generating graphics output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the dashed lines.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DESCRIPTION='text-string' 

text-string 
is a string up to 256 characters long. This is a comment field and does not affect the graphics output.

Provides a description of the device entry.

[Syntax: DEVMAP=device-map-StatementOptionName | NONE] 
          
 Specifies the device map to be used when device-resident fonts are used.

[Syntax: DEVOPTS='hardware-capabilities-hex-string'X] 
          
Specifies the hardware capabilities of the device.
Specifies the StatementOptionType of the output device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Indicates that the output device is a graphics device that will be receiving graphics data;  most device drivers use this value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Indicates that the output device is an IBM 3270 graphics data stream.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DRVINIT1='system-command(s)' | DRVINIT2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can be in upper- 
or lowercase letters.

Syntax: DRVINIT1='system-command(s)' | DRVINIT2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can be in upper- 
or lowercase letters.

Syntax: DRVTERM1='system-command(s)' | DRVTERM2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can be in upper- 
or lowercase letters.

Syntax: DRVTERM1='system-command(s)' | DRVTERM2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can be in upper- 
or lowercase letters.

Specifies whether to erase graph after display. 
          
ERASE is useful for those devices that overlay the graphics area and the message area - that is, 
those devices that have separate dialog box and graphics areas. On other devices, the graph is erased.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the graph to be erased when you press RETURN after the graph has been displayed.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes the graph to remain on the display when you press RETURN after the graph has been displayed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Controls when the graphics stream file (GSF) is closed when you are using the device driver 
to send graphics output to a hard copy device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Closes the GSF and makes it available to the device after all graphs have been produced and the  procedure or driver terminates.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Closes the GSF after each separate graph is produced and releases it to the device before sending another.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware rectangle-filling capability of the device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware rectangle-filling capability of the device.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software fills to fill rectangles.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the number of pixels to move before drawing the next line in a software fill of a 
solid area. 

Range: 0-9999.

If FILLINC is set to 0 or 1, adjacent lines are used (solid fill with no gaps). If FILLINC is set 
to 2, a pixel-width line is skipped before drawing the next line of a fill.

Sets the file format of the metacode file produced by the SAS-supplied part of the Metagraphics 
device driver. A blank field defaults to CHARACTER.

[Syntax: GACCESS=output-format | 'output-format destination'] 
          
Specifies the format or the destination or both of graphics data written to a device or graphics 
stream file (GSF).

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that a continuous stream of data is written.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the file be host-specific edit format.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that fixed-length records be written.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that records are to be written to the SAS log.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies that the records are to be written to the destination whose fileref is GSASFILE.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GCOPIES=(<current-copies><,max-copies>)] 
    
Sets the current and maximum number of copies to print.

Instructs the driver to issue either an FSCOPY or GSCOPY call to GDDM when AUTOCOPY 
is in effect.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Used when sending output to an IEEE attached plotter.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Used when creating an ADMPRINT file for output on 3287-StatementOptionType printers.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GEND='string' <...'string-n'>] 
          
Appends an ASCII string to every graphics data record that is sent to a device or file.

[Syntax: GEPILOG='string' <...'string-n'>] 
          
Sends a string to a device or file after all graphics commands are sent.
    
'string' can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'

[Syntax: GPROLOG='string' <...'string-n'>] 
          
Sends a string to device or file before graphics commands are sent.
    
'string' can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'

Specifies the protocol module to use when routing output directly to a printer or 
creating a graphics stream file (GSF) to send to a device attached to your host 
by a protocol converter.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip12: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip13: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip14: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip15: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip16: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip17: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip18: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip19: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip20: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip21: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip22: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip23: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip24: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip25: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip26: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GSFLEN=record-length] 
          
Controls the length of records written to the graphics stream file (GSF).
    
record-length: must be a nonnegative integer up to five digits long (0...99999).

Specifies the disposition of records written to a graphics stream file (GSF) or to 
a device or communications port by the device driver.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Adds the records to the end of a GSF designated by the GACCESS= or GSFNAME= graphics option or  device parameter.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sends the records to a device or communications port.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Replaces the existing contents of a GSF designated by the GACCESS= or GSFNAME= graphics option  or device parameter.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the fileref of the file or aggregate file location to which graphics stream 
file records are written.

Sets the number of lines of display used for graphics for devices whose displays can be divided into 
graphics and text areas.

Syntax: GSTART='string <...'string-n'>  

'string' 
can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'
 
Prefixes every record of graphics data sent to a device or file with a string of characters. 

GSTART is useful when sending a file to a device that requires each record be prefixed with some 
character. You can use GSTART= in conjunction with the GEND= graphics option or device parameter.
Specifies the StatementOptionType of flow control used to regulate the flow of data to a hard copy device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH instruct the device to use the hardware CTS and RTS signals.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH send data without providing flow control. Specify NONE only if the hardware  or interface program you are using provides its own flow control.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH use programmed flow control with plotters in eavesdrop mode.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH instruct the device to use ASCII characters DC1 and DC3.  (This is not appropriate for some devices.)

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: HEADER='command'] 
          
Specifies the command that executes a user-supplied program to create HEADER records for the driver.

[Syntax: HEADERFILE=fileref] 
          
Specifies the fileref for the file from which the Metagraphics driver reads HEADER records.

[Syntax: HORIGIN=horizontal-offset <IN | CM | PT>]
    
Sets the horizontal offset from the lower-left corner of the display area to the lower-left 
corner of the graph.

[Syntax: HOSTSPEC='text-string'] 
          
Stores FILENAME statement options in the device entry.

[Syntax: HSIZE=horizontal-size <IN | CM | PT>]
    
Sets the horizontal size of the graphics output area.

[Syntax: ID='description'] 
          
Specifies the description string used by the Metagraphics driver.
Sets level of interactivity for Metagraphics driver.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the user-written part of the driver be executed outside of SAS/GRAPH.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the user-written part of the Metagraphics driver be invoked after the procedure  is complete.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that the user-written part be invoked for each graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LFACTOR=line-thickness-factor] 
          
Selects the default hardware line thickness.

Syntax: MAXCOLORS=number-of-colors  

number-of-colors 
must be an integer in the range 2 through 256. The total number of colors includes the foreground 
colors plus the background color.

Sets the total number of colors that can be displayed at once.

The PENMOUNTS= graphics option overrides the value of MAXCOLORS.

Syntax: MAXPOLY=number-of-vertices  

number-of-vertices 
is a nonnegative integer up to four digits long. A value of 0 means that there is no limit to the 
number of vertices that can be specified in the hardware's polygon-drawing command. The maximum 
value of MAXPOLY depends on the number of vertices your device can process.

Sets the maximum number of vertices for hardware-drawn polygons.

Syntax: MODEL=model-number  

model-number 
is a nonnegative integer up to five digits long that is the SAS-designated model number for the 
corresponding device. It is not the same as a manufacturer's model number.

Specifies the model number of the output device. 

Do not change this field in SAS-supplied drivers or in drivers that you copy from SAS-supplied drivers.

Syntax: PAPERFEED=feed-increment <IN | CM> 
    
Specifies the increment of paper that is ejected when a graph is completed. 
    
feed-increment must be a nonnegative number and can be followed by a unit specification, 
either IN for inches (default) or CM for centimeters.

[Syntax: PATH=angle-increment  

angle-increment 
is an integer in the range 0 to 360 that specifies the angle at which to rotate the text baseline. 
A value of 0 means that the device uses its default orientation. Specify 0 if your device does not 
perform string angling in hardware.

Sets the increment of the angle for device-resident text rotation.
Specifies whether plotters draw graphics elements in order of color.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the plotter to draw all graphics elements of one color at one time. For example, it draws  all the red elements in the output, then all the blue elements, and so on. This specification is  compatible with previous releases. Use it for plotters with real pens.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes the plotter to draw each element as it is encountered, regardless of its color. For example,  the plotter might draw a red circle, then a blue line, and then a red line, and so on. This method  is best for electrostatic printers implemented with Metagraphics drivers of TYPE=PLOTTER. In addition,  this option enables you to specify non-standard color names.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to use the device's hardware pie-fill capability.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware capability of the device, if available, to fill pies  and pie sections.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to fill pies and pie sections using software pie fills.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to use the hardware polygon-fill capability.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware capability of the device to fill polygons.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software fills to fill polygons.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: POSTGRAPH1='system-command(s)'

where: 

system-command(s) 
specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- or 
lowercase characters.

Syntax: POSTGRAPH2='system-command(s)'

where: 

system-command(s) 
specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- or 
lowercase characters.

Syntax: PREGRAPH1='system-command(s)' where:
    
system-command(s) specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- 
or lowercase characters.

Syntax: PREGRAPH2='system-command(s)' where:
    
system-command(s) specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- 
or lowercase characters.

Syntax: PROCESSINPUT=fileref  

fileref 
specifies a valid SAS fileref up to eight characters long. Fileref must be assigned with 
a FILENAME statement or a host command before running the Metagraphics driver. 

Specifies the fileref for the file that contains input for the user-written part of the 
Metagraphics driver.

Syntax: PROCESSOUTPUT=fileref  

fileref 
specifies a valid SAS fileref up to eight characters long. Fileref must be assigned with a 
FILENAME statement or a host command before running the Metagraphics driver.
Specifies whether prompts are issued.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Provides no prompting
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Issues startup messages only. Startup messages are messages such as PLEASE PRESS RETURN TO CONTINUE.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Signals end of graph if device is a video display or sends message to change paper if device is a plotter.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Sends a message to mount pens if the device is a plotter.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PROMPTCHARS='prompt-chars-hex-string'X] 
          
Selects the prompt characters to be used by SAS/GRAPH device drivers.
Specifies whether log messages are held until after the graphics output is displayed.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Queues driver messages while the device is in graphics mode (default for video devices).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Prevents the queuing of messages (default for plotters, cameras, and printers).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies how many times to redraw the graph.

Syntax: REPAINT=redraw-factor where:

redraw-factor is a nonnegative integer up to three digits long (0...999).
Specifies whether and how to rotate the graph.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies landscape orientation (the graph is wider than it is high).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies portrait orientation (the graph is higher than it is wide).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Selects pen speed for plotters with variable speed selection.
    
Syntax: SPEED=pen-speed where:

pen-speed specifies a percentage (1 through 100) of the maximum pen speed for the device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Swaps BLACK for WHITE and vice versa.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Does not swap the colors.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to use the device's symbol-drawing capability.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in symbol-drawing capability of the device, if available.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the symbols using SAS/GRAPH fonts.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SYMBOLS='hardware-symbols-hex-string'X 

hardware-symbols-hex-string 
is a hexadecimal string that is 16 characters long and must be completely filled.

Specifies which symbols can be generated by hardware. For example, if you want the driver to do only 
the PLUS and X symbols in hardware, the first and second bits of the first byte of the hexadecimal 
string should be turned on, which would correspond to a value of 'C000000000000000'X ('C0'X is 
equivalent to '1 1 0 0 0 0 0 0' in binary).

Syntax: TRAILER='command' 
          
command 
specifies a command that runs a user-written program that creates the TRAILER file. 
Command is a string up to 40 characters long.

Specifies the command that creates TRAILER records for the Metagraphics driver.

Syntax: TRAILERFILE=fileref 
          
fileref
specifies a valid SAS fileref up to eight characters long. Fileref must have been previously 
assigned with a FILENAME statement or a host command before running the Metagraphics driver. 

Specifies the fileref of the file from which the Metagraphics driver reads TRAILER records.

Selects a translate table for your system that performs ASCII-to-EBCDIC translation.
    
Syntax: TRANTAB=table | user-defined-table w

here:

table: specifies a translate table stored as a SAS/GRAPH catalog entry. Table can be one of the following: 

      SASGTAB0 (default translate table for your operating environment)
 
      GTABVTAM
 
      GTABTCAM 

user-defined-table: specifies the StatementOptionName of a user-created translate table.
Specifies the type of output device to which graphics commands are sent.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a film-recording device.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a monitor or terminal.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Identifies the list in which the device appears under SAS/ASSIST software. This is used for drivers  that produce output to be exported to other software applications, such as CGM or HPGL.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Sets the user-defined control characters for the device.
    
Syntax: UCC='control-characters-hex-string'X where:

control-characters-hex-string is a hexadecimal string that can be up 32 bytes (64 characters) long.

Sets the vertical offset from the lower-left corner of the display area to the 
lower-left corner of the graph.
    
Syntax: VORIGIN=vertical-offset <IN | CM | PT> where:

vertical-offset must be a nonnegative number and can be followed by a unit specification, 
either IN for inches (default), or CM for centimeters, or PT for points.

Sets the vertical size of the graphics output area.
    
Syntax: VSIZE=vertical-size <IN | CM | PT> where:

vertical-size specifies the height of the graphics output area; 
vertical-size must be a positive number and can be followed by a unit specification, 
either IN for inches (default), or CM for centimeters, or PT for points.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Sets the file format of the metacode file to character.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sets the file format of the metacode file to binary

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: FROM=<libref.>SAS catalog] 
          
Names the catalog from which to copy device-entry.

[Syntax: NEWNAME=new-device-entry] 
          
Specifies a name for the copy of the device entry that is placed in the current catalog.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Deletes the device entry from the current catalog. 
      
Syntax: DELETE device-entry;
      
where: 

device-entry 
specifies the one-level name of device entry to delete. 

Restriction: The entry must exist in the current catalog.

Syntax: FS;
      
Switches from program mode to the GDEVICE windows.

Syntax: LIST <device-entry> <_ALL_> <_NEXT_> <_PREV_> <DUMP>; 
        
Lists all of the parameters of the specified device entry in the Output window.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Lists only the name, description, and creation date of all device entries in the current catalog. 
If no entries exist in the catalog, the GDEVICE procedure issues a message.

Lists the contents of the next device entry. The GDEVICE procedure lists the first entry in the 
catalog if no entries have been previously listed.

Lists the contents of the previous device entry. If you have not previously listed the contents
of a device entry, the GDEVICE procedure issues this message: 

  No objects preceding current object.
Lists detailed information on all device entries in the current catalog.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: MODIFY device-entry parameter(s); 
      
Changes the values in a device entry.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: MODULE=driver-module] 
          
Specifies the name of the corresponding executable driver module for the device.

[Syntax: XMAX=width <IN | CM | PT>] 
          
Specifies the width of the addressable graphics display area; affects the horizontal resolution 
of the device and the horizontal dimension of the graphics output area.

[Syntax: YMAX=height <IN | CM | PT>] 
          
Specifies the height of the addressable graphics display area; affects the vertical resolution 
of the device and the vertical dimension of the graphics output area.

[Syntax: XPIXELS=width-in-pixels] 
          
Specifies the width of the addressable display area in pixels and in conjunction with XMAX 
determines the horizontal resolution for the device.

[Syntax: YPIXELS=height-in-pixels] 
          
Specifies the height of the addressable display area in pixels and in conjunction with YMAX 
determines the horizontal resolution for the device.

[Syntax: LCOLS=landscape-columns] 
          
Sets the number of columns in the graphics output area for landscape orientation.

[Syntax: LROWS=landscape-rows] 
          
Sets the number of rows in the graphics output area for landscape orientation.

[Syntax: PCOLS=portrait-columns] 
          
Sets the number of columns in the graphics output area for portrait orientation.

[Syntax: PROWS=portrait-rows] 
          
Sets the number of rows in the graphics output area for portrait orientation.

Syntax: ASPECT=scaling-factor

where scaling-factor is a nonnegative integer or real number that determines the ratio of width to 
height for graphics elements. If you specify ASPECT=1, each graphics element has equal horizontal 
and vertical scaling factors; ASPECT=2 scales the graphics element twice as wide as its height; 
and so on. If ASPECT= is not specified or is set to 0 or null, SAS/GRAPH uses the aspect ratio 
of the hardware device.
Specifies whether to generate hard copy automatically.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Prints a copy of the graph automatically.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Suppresses printing a copy of the graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies whether devices with continuous paper or automatic paper feed should roll or feed the paper 
 automatically for the next graph. 
 
 For PostScript devices, if AUTOFEED is unaltered, the PostScript file is unchanged. If you specify 
 NOAUTOFEED and do not select a PPD file with the PPDFILE option, a PostScript Level 1 MANUALFEED 
 command is added to the driver output. If you specify NOAUTOFEED and select a PPD that contains a 
 MANUALFEED option, the procedure code for that MANUALFEED option is sent. If there is no MANUALFEED 
 option in the PPD, no MANUALFEED code is sent.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the device to feed new paper automatically for the next graph.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Suppresses the automatic paper feed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the background color of the graphics output.
Controls whether to use cell alignment.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the device to use cell alignment. In that case SAS/GRAPH attempts to place hardware (or simulated  hardware) characters inside character cells. This restriction on the location of characters means that  in some cases the SAS/GRAPH procedure can generate axes that do not occupy the entire procedure output  area or might be unable to create the requested graph.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Suppresses cell alignment, causing the procedure to use the entire procedure output area and place  axis and tick mark labels without regard to cell alignment.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies whether the device--resident font is used when no font or FONT=NONE is specified in a SAS 
statement. 

The device--resident font is not used if you changed the HPOS= and VPOS= graphics options from 
the default, or if you used the HEIGHT= option in a SAS statement and the device does not have 
scalable characters.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the device-resident font when you do not specify a font in a SAS program.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the characters using the SIMULATE font and suppresses the use of all  device--resident fonts, regardless of values you specify in other SAS statements.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies a device-resident font by associating a CHARTYPE number with a device-resident font. 
Also defines a default size to use with that font.

Syntax: CHARTYPE=hardware-font-chartype  

hardware-font-chartype 
is a nonnegative integer from 0 to 999. hardware-font-chartype refers to the actual number for 
the device-resident font you want to use as listed in the Chartype window of the device entry 
for the selected device driver. By default, CHARTYPE is 0, which is the default device-resident 
font for the device.
          
Selects the number of the default hardware character set.
Specifies whether SAS/GRAPH should use the device's hardware circle-drawing capability, if available.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware circle- and arc-drawing capability of the device.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software move and draw commands to draw circles and arcs.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CMAP=('from-color : to-color' <...,'from-color-n : to-color-n'>)
    
Specifies a color map for the device.

[Syntax: COLORS=<(colors-list | NONE)>] 
          
Specifies the foreground colors used to produce your graphics output if you do not 
specify colors explicitly in program statements.
Specifies a color StatementOptionType.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: SAS predefined color names.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Red-green-blue (RGB) color specifications.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to use the device's hardware dashed-line capability, if available.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware dashed-line drawing capability of the device when  generating graphics output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the dashed lines.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DESCRIPTION='text-string' 

text-string 
is a string up to 256 characters long. This is a comment field and does not affect the graphics output.

Provides a description of the device entry.

[Syntax: DEVMAP=device-map-StatementOptionName | NONE] 
          
 Specifies the device map to be used when device-resident fonts are used.

[Syntax: DEVOPTS='hardware-capabilities-hex-string'X] 
          
Specifies the hardware capabilities of the device.
Specifies the StatementOptionType of the output device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Indicates that the output device is a graphics device that will be receiving graphics data;  most device drivers use this value.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Indicates that the output device is an IBM 3270 graphics data stream.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: DRVINIT1='system-command(s)' | DRVINIT2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can be in upper- 
or lowercase letters.

Syntax: DRVINIT1='system-command(s)' | DRVINIT2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can be in upper- 
or lowercase letters.

Syntax: DRVTERM1='system-command(s)' | DRVTERM2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can be in upper- 
or lowercase letters.

Syntax: DRVTERM1='system-command(s)' | DRVTERM2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can be in upper- 
or lowercase letters.

Specifies whether to erase graph after display. 
          
ERASE is useful for those devices that overlay the graphics area and the message area - that is, 
those devices that have separate dialog box and graphics areas. On other devices, the graph is erased.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the graph to be erased when you press RETURN after the graph has been displayed.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes the graph to remain on the display when you press RETURN after the graph has been displayed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Controls when the graphics stream file (GSF) is closed when you are using the device driver 
to send graphics output to a hard copy device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Closes the GSF and makes it available to the device after all graphs have been  produced and the procedure or driver terminates.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Closes the GSF after each separate graph is produced and releases it to the device before  sending another.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware rectangle-filling capability of the device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware rectangle-filling capability of the device.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software fills to fill rectangles.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the number of pixels to move before drawing the next line in a software 
fill of a solid area. 

Range: 0-9999.

If FILLINC is set to 0 or 1, adjacent lines are used (solid fill with no gaps). If FILLINC is set 
to 2, a pixel-width line is skipped before drawing the next line of a fill.

Sets the file format of the metacode file produced by the SAS-supplied part of the 
Metagraphics device driver. A blank field defaults to CHARACTER.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Sets the file format of the metacode file to character.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sets the file format of the metacode file to binary

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GACCESS=output-format | 'output-format destination'] 
          
Specifies the format or the destination or both of graphics data written to a device or graphics 
stream file (GSF).

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that a continuous stream of data is written.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the file be host-specific edit format.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that fixed-length records be written.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that records are to be written to the SAS log.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies that the records are to be written to the destination whose fileref is GSASFILE.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GCOPIES=(<current-copies><,max-copies>)] 
    
Sets the current and maximum number of copies to print.
Instructs the driver to issue either an FSCOPY or GSCOPY call to GDDM when AUTOCOPY is in effect.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Used when sending output to an IEEE attached plotter.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Used when creating an ADMPRINT file for output on 3287-StatementOptionType printers.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GEND='string' <...'string-n'>] 
          
Appends an ASCII string to every graphics data record that is sent to a device or file.

[Syntax: GEPILOG='string' <...'string-n'>] 
          
Sends a string to a device or file after all graphics commands are sent.
    
'string' can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'

[Syntax: GPROLOG='string' <...'string-n'>] 
          
Sends a string to device or file before graphics commands are sent.
    
'string' can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'

Specifies the protocol module to use when routing output directly to a printer 
or creating a graphics stream file (GSF) to send to a device attached to your 
host by a protocol converter.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip12: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip13: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip14: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip15: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip16: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip17: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip18: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip19: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip20: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip21: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip22: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip23: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip24: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip25: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip26: Protocol module StatementOptionName. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: GSFLEN=record-length] 
          
Controls the length of records written to the graphics stream file (GSF).
    
record-length: must be a nonnegative integer up to five digits long (0...99999).

Specifies the disposition of records written to a graphics stream file (GSF) or to 
a device or communications port by the device driver.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Adds the records to the end of a GSF designated by the GACCESS= or GSFNAME=  graphics option or device parameter.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sends the records to a device or communications port.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Replaces the existing contents of a GSF designated by the GACCESS= or GSFNAME= graphics option  or device parameter.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the fileref of the file or aggregate file location to which graphics 
stream file records are written.

Sets the number of lines of display used for graphics for devices whose displays can 
be divided into graphics and text areas.

Syntax: GSTART='string <...'string-n'>  

'string' 
can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'
 
Prefixes every record of graphics data sent to a device or file with a string of characters. 

GSTART is useful when sending a file to a device that requires each record be prefixed with some 
character. You can use GSTART= in conjunction with the GEND= graphics option or device parameter.

Specifies the StatementOptionType of flow control used to regulate the flow of data 
to a hard copy device.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH instruct the device to use the hardware CTS and RTS signals.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH send data without providing flow control. Specify NONE  only if the hardware or interface program you are using provides its own flow  control.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH use programmed flow control with plotters in eavesdrop mode.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH instruct the device to use ASCII characters DC1 and DC3.  (This is not appropriate for some devices.)

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: HEADER='command'] 
          
Specifies the command that executes a user-supplied program to create HEADER records 
for the driver.

[Syntax: HEADERFILE=fileref] 
          
Specifies the fileref for the file from which the Metagraphics driver reads HEADER records.

[Syntax: HORIGIN=horizontal-offset <IN | CM | PT>]
    
Sets the horizontal offset from the lower-left corner of the display area to the lower-left 
corner of the graph.

[Syntax: HOSTSPEC='text-string'] 
          
Stores FILENAME statement options in the device entry.

[Syntax: HSIZE=horizontal-size <IN | CM | PT>]
    
Sets the horizontal size of the graphics output area.

[Syntax: ID='description'] 
          
Specifies the description string used by the Metagraphics driver.
Sets level of interactivity for Metagraphics driver.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the user-written part of the driver be executed outside of SAS/GRAPH.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the user-written part of the Metagraphics driver be invoked after the procedure  is complete.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that the user-written part be invoked for each graph.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: LFACTOR=line-thickness-factor] 
          
Selects the default hardware line thickness.

Syntax: MAXCOLORS=number-of-colors  

number-of-colors 
must be an integer in the range 2 through 256. The total number of colors includes 
the foreground colors plus the background color.

Sets the total number of colors that can be displayed at once.

The PENMOUNTS= graphics option overrides the value of MAXCOLORS.

Syntax: MAXPOLY=number-of-vertices  

number-of-vertices 
is a nonnegative integer up to four digits long. A value of 0 means that there is 
no limit to the number of vertices that can be specified in the hardware's polygon-
drawing command. The maximum value of MAXPOLY depends on the number of vertices your 
device can process.

Sets the maximum number of vertices for hardware-drawn polygons.

Syntax: MODEL=model-number  

model-number 
is a nonnegative integer up to five digits long that is the SAS-designated model number for the 
corresponding device. It is not the same as a manufacturer's model number.

Specifies the model number of the output device. 

Do not change this field in SAS-supplied drivers or in drivers that you copy from SAS-supplied drivers.

Syntax: PAPERFEED=feed-increment <IN | CM> 
    
Specifies the increment of paper that is ejected when a graph is completed. 
    
feed-increment must be a nonnegative number and can be followed by a unit specification, either 
IN for inches (default) or CM for centimeters.

[Syntax: PATH=angle-increment  

angle-increment 
is an integer in the range 0 to 360 that specifies the angle at which to rotate the text baseline. 
A value of 0 means that the device uses its default orientation. Specify 0 if your device does not 
perform string angling in hardware.

Sets the increment of the angle for device-resident text rotation.
Specifies whether plotters draw graphics elements in order of color.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the plotter to draw all graphics elements of one color at one time. For example, it draws  all the red elements in the output, then all the blue elements, and so on. This specification is  compatible with previous releases. Use it for plotters with real pens.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes the plotter to draw each element as it is encountered, regardless of its color. For example,  the plotter might draw a red circle, then a blue line, and then a red line, and so on. This method  is best for electrostatic printers implemented with Metagraphics drivers of TYPE=PLOTTER. In addition,  this option enables you to specify non-standard color names.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to use the device's hardware pie-fill capability.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware capability of the device, if available, to fill pies  and pie sections.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to fill pies and pie sections using software pie fills.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to use the hardware polygon-fill capability.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware capability of the device to fill polygons.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software fills to fill polygons.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: POSTGRAPH1='system-command(s)'

where: 

system-command(s) 
specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- or 
lowercase characters.

Syntax: POSTGRAPH2='system-command(s)'

where: 

system-command(s) 
specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- or 
lowercase characters.

Syntax: PREGRAPH1='system-command(s)' where:
    
system-command(s) specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- or lowercase characters.

Syntax: PREGRAPH2='system-command(s)' where:
    
system-command(s) specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- or lowercase characters.

Syntax: PROCESSINPUT=fileref  

fileref 
specifies a valid SAS fileref up to eight characters long. Fileref must be assigned 
with a FILENAME statement or a host command before running the Metagraphics driver. 

Specifies the fileref for the file that contains input for the user-written part of the 
Metagraphics driver.
Specifies whether prompts are issued.

Syntax: PROCESSOUTPUT=fileref  

fileref 
specifies a valid SAS fileref up to eight characters long. Fileref must be assigned with a 
FILENAME statement or a host command before running the Metagraphics driver.
Specifies whether prompts are issued.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Provides no prompting
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Issues startup messages only. Startup messages are messages such as PLEASE PRESS RETURN TO CONTINUE.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Signals end of graph if device is a video display or sends message to change paper if device is a plotter.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Sends a message to mount pens if the device is a plotter.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PROMPTCHARS='prompt-chars-hex-string'X] 
          
Selects the prompt characters to be used by SAS/GRAPH device drivers.
Specifies whether log messages are held until after the graphics output is displayed.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Queues driver messages while the device is in graphics mode (default for video devices).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Prevents the queuing of messages (default for plotters, cameras, and printers).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies how many times to redraw the graph.

Syntax: REPAINT=redraw-factor where:

redraw-factor is a nonnegative integer up to three digits long (0...999).
Specifies whether and how to rotate the graph.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies landscape orientation (the graph is wider than it is high).
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies portrait orientation (the graph is higher than it is wide).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Selects pen speed for plotters with variable speed selection.
    
Syntax: SPEED=pen-speed where:

pen-speed specifies a percentage (1 through 100) of the maximum pen speed for the device.
Specifies whether to use the device's symbol-drawing capability.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Swaps BLACK for WHITE and vice versa.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Does not swap the colors.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to use the device's symbol-drawing capability.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in symbol-drawing capability of the device, if available.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the symbols using SAS/GRAPH fonts.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SYMBOLS='hardware-symbols-hex-string'X 

hardware-symbols-hex-string 
is a hexadecimal string that is 16 characters long and must be completely filled.

Specifies which symbols can be generated by hardware. For example, if you want the 
driver to do only the PLUS and X symbols in hardware, the first and second bits of 
the first byte of the hexadecimal string should be turned on, which would correspond 
to a value of 'C000000000000000'X ('C0'X is equivalent to '1 1 0 0 0 0 0 0' in binary).

Syntax: TRAILER='command' 
          
command 
specifies a command that runs a user-written program that creates the TRAILER file. 
Command is a string up to 40 characters long.

Specifies the command that creates TRAILER records for the Metagraphics driver.

Syntax: TRAILERFILE=fileref 
          
fileref
specifies a valid SAS fileref up to eight characters long. Fileref must have been previously 
assigned with a FILENAME statement or a host command before running the Metagraphics driver. 

Specifies the fileref of the file from which the Metagraphics driver reads TRAILER records.

Selects a translate table for your system that performs ASCII-to-EBCDIC translation.
    
Syntax: TRANTAB=table | user-defined-table 

where:

table: specifies a translate table stored as a SAS/GRAPH catalog entry. Table can 
be one of the following: 

      SASGTAB0 (default translate table for your operating environment)
 
      GTABVTAM
 
      GTABTCAM 

user-defined-table: specifies the StatementOptionName of a user-created translate table.
Specifies the type of output device to which graphics commands are sent.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies a film-recording device.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies a monitor or terminal.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Identifies the list in which the device appears under SAS/ASSIST software. This  is used for drivers that produce output to be exported to other software  applications, such as CGM or HPGL.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Sets the user-defined control characters for the device.
    
Syntax: UCC='control-characters-hex-string'X where:

control-characters-hex-string is a hexadecimal string that can be up 32 bytes (64 characters) long.

Sets the vertical offset from the lower-left corner of the display area to the 
lower-left corner of the graph.
    
Syntax: VORIGIN=vertical-offset <IN | CM | PT> where:

vertical-offset must be a nonnegative number and can be followed by a unit specification, 
either IN for inches (default), or CM for centimeters, or PT for points.

Sets the vertical size of the graphics output area.
    
Syntax: VSIZE=vertical-size <IN | CM | PT> where:

vertical-size specifies the height of the graphics output area; 
vertical-size must be a positive number and can be followed by a unit specification, 
either IN for inches (default), or CM for centimeters, or PT for points.

StatementHelp.#cdata: Saves all modifications made to device entries during the procedure. Exits the GDEVICE procedure.
Saves all modifications made to device entries during the procedure. Exits the GDEVICE procedure.
Saves all modifications made to device entries during the procedure. Exits the GDEVICE procedure.

Syntax: RENAME device-entry NEWNAME=entry-name; 
        
Changes the name of the device entry to the name specified in the statement.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: NEWNAME=entry-name] 
          
Specifies the new entry name. Entry-name must be a valid name for a SAS catalog entry 
and cannot already exist in the current catalog. If the name already exists, the GDEVICE 
procedure issues an error message.
